They are sexually dimorphic, with the females being significantly larger than the males.

The spider's body is typically golden-yellow or cinnamon-brown in color, with a distinctive pattern of dark markings on the abdomen. Their legs are also patterned with dark and light bands. The species is known for the high-quality silk it produces, which is used to create its web. This silk is considered one of the strongest natural fibers known to science.

Trichonephila clavipes is an important part of the ecosystem, serving as both a predator and prey within the food web. They feed on a variety of insects and small vertebrates that become entangled in their webs. The species is also an important pollinator, as the spiders attract various insects that become trapped in the web, subsequently aiding in the transfer of pollen.
